p: There are incomplete data regarding climate change and other tick-borne diseases. Some studies have indicated that the Mediterranean basin is becoming more hospitable for the spread of Crimean–Congo haemorrhagic fever (Maltezou and Papa 2010), but socio-economic development, agricultural practices and land use changes may be more significant contributors (Estrada-Peña et al. 2012). There has been a range expansion of Rickettsia in recent years, but the underlying reasons are not clear (Gouriet, Rolain and Raoult 2006) and few investigations have examined the association between climate change and this disease.
